ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a fully online discussion format.
none
n/a

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned Chinese grammar, practiced speaking and reading. Due to the online format, there was relatively little writing practice.
Developing better reading skills in Chinese; using more professional and idiomatic terms in conversation and writing.
I gained deep knowledge and a greater understanding of Chinese
You learn a lot of chinese vocabulary and sentence structures in a variety of contexts.
I learned new/more advanced vocabulary and grammar structures.

I learned a lot of new vocabulary, grammar structures and idioms. I was surprised at how little I actually knew going into the class and how much more I knew coming out. I also learned a ton about culture, reading and writing skills, speaking skills.
Chinese speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills
Expanded vocabulary and grammatical structures
Learned grammar and vocabulary for L5 Chinese on the heritage track as well as some background on traditional and modern Chinese culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think having more emphasis on writing would be useful - in previous Chinese courses there was a daily written quiz which forced students to learn how to write new characters. But I suppose this would have been more difficult given the online format.

Strengths: Prof. Wang is really engaging and energetic; really comprehensive textbook; good pacing of workload and projects
Weaknesses: Grading system for homework was slightly vague
Strengths: Wang Laoshi was very engaging and the lectures were very interesting
The class is very engaging, but oftentimes there is not enough class time to go over everything. In an online setting, there are also technical issues.

In previous Chinese classes at Yale, there were one-on-one tutorial sessions where students could meet with a teacher and get practice speaking one on one. There wasn't anything like that for this course.

This course was very engaging and you learn a lot by the end. It builds a good foundation if you want to continue studying Chinese. If not, it is a good point to stop since you will feel satisfied with how much you improved by the end. One weakness is that the course is a bit disorganized and chaotic. The homework due dates and details about certain assignments can be extremely confusing or not updated from the year before.

Strengths: engaging professor, learned a lot
Weaknesses: Directions for assignments was sometimes confusing/disorganized, in-class engagement was sometimes awkward

Strengths - classes are generally discussion based, liked the formatting of each chapter with a text, vocab, grammar, and practice sections
Weaknesses - sometimes felt like you would learn new chapters but slowly forget the previous ones
The course material was useful and well-organized. There could maybe have been more blending of earlier lessons with the later lessons to help us retain the content.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Even despite the difficult virtual format, Prof. Wang still made the course very engaging and fostered a sense of community.

I really liked that the language classes continued to be held in a very engaging setting (synchronous class as opposed to asynchronous). There was still a lot of engaging material with the projects and class material, which was very nice.

Since this is a language class, it is necessary for students to talk and engage. This course did a good job in having us talk as much as possible, but compared to a real classroom, it still felt a bit awkward at times. I cant really think of any ways to make the class more engaging.

Virtual seminars could be improved to offer more opportunities for participation
Canvas discussion posts were confusing

Because of the COVID situation, tests were done online and thus with pinyin. This made the tests a lot simpler but also meant that you didn't learn to hand write characters as much - could be seen as a positive or negative.

We used the Zoom chat function to write sentences and breakout rooms to have smaller discussions with other students. Because of the online format, though, it was harder to get totally immersed in the language learning environment.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It is quite the enjoyable learning experience!
Yes, I would recommend this course to students who like a small classroom setting and high engagement levels
Yes! This class is super fun, especially with Wang laoshi, and overall, you learn a lot of Chinese, but also about your identity as a heritage speaker.
Yes! Wang laoshi is a very good professor and she makes the class very fun and natural.
I would definitely recommend this class! It is quite rigorous, but you learn so much.
I would recommend this course to students looking to improve their Chinese skills. It was engaging and helpful.

I feel like you'll know if you want to take this course. If you're interested in taking Chinese, are at the L5-1 native level, then take the course. The design of the course is accommodating even if you are slightly more/less advanced.
I would recommend this course to other heritage speakers looking to improve their skills in Chinese.
